page.title: 01KYNASTON'S CAVE NESSCLIFFE
page.content: Kynaston's Cave is up on Nesscliffe Hill .Humphrey Kynaston the highway man lived in about 1650. He kept the horse with him in the cave, carved out of the rock up a flight of steps.There was a window,a door and two rooms, one for himself and one for the horse. In the doorway you can still see the bolts for the door. There are shelves carved in the sandstone. A chimney goes diagonally out of the cave. S ome say he put the horses hooves on backwards. No-one really knows. Many things were attributed to Kynaston,such as turning the horse hooves round to stop the soldiers catching him.However,this was said of many highwaymen.The cave is very near the main road so it would not have been difficult for him to find people to rob.
